intro: Eurydochus cortesii, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, orange to red composite flowers. The plant typically grows as an annual herb, reaching heights of up to 2 meters, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers bloom in late summer to early fall, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Eurydochus cortesii is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in a variety of soil conditions.
